material.mattext: Which of the following statements is true?
The alert(), prompt() and confirm() methods are all methods of the window object.
The alert(), prompt() and confirm() methods all have return values.
The alert(), prompt() and confirm() methods are all launched only by the primary event.
The alert(), prompt() and confirm() methods all allow you to communicate with the user by collecting input.
Which of the following statements uses correct syntax for the alert() method?
alert("This is a message for the user");
document.alert("This is a message for the user");
alert(This is a message for the user);
document.alert(This is a message for the user)
When are semicolons generally used in JavaScript?
To separate statements when there is more than one statement present
At the end of every statement
Never, because they are not required in JavaScript
At the end of every line that does not include a method call
Which code correctly scripts a JavaScript prompt() method?
prompt("This text asks for user input.", "This default text appears in the text input area.");
prompt("This text asks for user input."; "This default text appears in the text input area.");
prompt ("This default text appears in the text input area."),("This text asks for user input.");
prompt("This default text appears in the text input area.", "This text asks for user input.");
Which JavaScript operator indicates concatenation?

Consider the following code:

alert("Hello " + prompt("what is your name?", "");

 

Assuming the user's name is Jon, what would the resulting dialog box display when he runs this script and enters his input?
The dialog will display: Hello Jon
The dialog will display: Hello what is your name?
The dialog will display: Hello what is your name? Jon
The dialog will display: Hello

Consider the following JavaScript code:

alert("hello " + "world");


What is the result when this script is run in the browser?
One dialog box displaying hello world
Two dialog boxes, one displaying hello and one displaying world
One dialog requesting information, and displaying hello world as the default value
One dialog displaying undefined
Which method is used to ask the user a true-or-false type of question?
The confirm() method
The alert() method
The open() method
The prompt() method
Which of the following is a variable data type supported by JavaScript?
String
Integer
No value
Alphanumeric

Consider the following code:

 
let myVar;
myVar = confirm("continue?");

What is the data type of the value of myVar after execution?
Boolean
Bit
It depends on the user's input
Undefined

Consider the following code:

let myVar1 = "25";
let myVar2 = 25;


What is the difference between myVar1 and myVar2?
The data type
Nothing, they are the same
The value
The scope

Consider the following code:

let yearOfBirth = 1978;
alert("YearOfBirth");


What would the resulting dialog box display?
The dialog will display: YearOfBirth
The dialog will display: 1978
The dialog will display: undefined
The dialog will display: yearOfBirth
Which statement uses proper JavaScript syntax for declaring variables?
let firstName = "Sal", lastName = "Fiore";
let ∼correctAnswer = "10";
let "userName = Inga";
let username == "Inga";
Which type of JavaScript expression evaluates to true or false?
Logical
Assignment
Arithmetic
String

Consider the following expression:

30 < 50;


What is the result of this expression?
The result is: true
The result is: 20
The result is: false
The result is: -20
Which of the following operators is an assignment operator?

Consider the following code:

var age = 18;
var testValue = (age < 21) ? 'Teenager': 'Adult';


What is the value of testValue after execution?
The value is: Teenager
The value is: 18
The value is: 21
The value is: 21

Consider the following expression:

newValue = 43 + 90


What is the result of this expression?
The result is: 133
The result is: 4390
The result is: null
The result is: 47

Consider the following expression:

newValue = "25" + "37"


What is the result of this expression?
The result is: 2537
The result is: 62
The result is: undefined
The result is: null
Which of the following expressions evaluates to true?
13 == "thirteen"
Which of the following is true of JavaScript keywords and/or reserved words?
You cannot use reserved words as names for objects.
You can use reserved words as names for variables.
You can use reserved words but not keywords as names for objects.
All keywords are specific to particular versions of JavaScript.
In JavaScript, what is a reserved word?
A keyword that cannot be used for any other purpose in JavaScript code
A container that holds a value
A character used in an expression to store or return a value in JavaScript code
Part of a statement evaluated as a value
Which method displays a simple message to the user but does not take any response?
The alert() method
The open() method
The prompt() method
The confirm() method
